subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Need common abbreviation list
msgSnippet: Hello Paul I have a table of abbreviations.  I will update it for you with the junior equivalents as my table is just a representation of the senior forms per
messageBody:
Hello Paul

I have a table of abbreviations.  I will update it for you with the junior equivalents as my table is just a representation of the senior forms per QM.  

You are doing great work on the news - I would love to see the BBC news feed converted.  I noticed that you had introduced the basic abbreviations with approval.  This will make it all the more readable.

I also applaud your decision to stick to the QM common endings as this will help enormously with readability.

regards

Moira

On 16/11/2007, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:

For the news, I would like to include the abbreviations that Read uses
in the QS manual. I would also like to use his spelling of the 70 most
common words. Last, I would like to start using some, if not all, of
Read's suggestions on common word endings, such as words ending in -ing
and -ed. However, I cannot read many of these words because of Read's
hand writing and my inexperience with QS. Plus, some of the letters
appear to be the half letters of Senior QS, such as the the double Deed
at the end of words.

For #1 and #2, I would like someone to submit the abbreviations as a
text attachment or in an email. In one column, put the TO word, and in
the next put the QS transcription.

For #3, I would like a list as in #1, with any explanation when to use
these ending, if it is not already clear.

In some of these cases, it appears that Read recommends using senior QS
letters, so should we try to use a Junior equivelent?

These contributions will help me make the news more readable. If anyone
has an objection to using any abbreviations, common words, or endings,
let me know.

Paul




--
Moira O'Brien
